medium_description_en: Estimates amount of a substance (e.g. antibody) remaining in the intravascular space after a given number of plasma volume exchanges.
short_description_en: Removal of a substance by plasma exchange.

seo.meta_description_en: Therapeutic Apheresis predicts residual relative concentration after removal or addition of a substance by apheresis.

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients who require therapeutic plasma exchange typically have a pathologic substance in circulation (e.g. an autoantibody) requiring removal. The amount of this substance remaining varies with the number of plasma volumes exchanged, with a plateau typically reached over time as the efficiencies of the procedure are reduced as higher amounts of replacement fluids are removed than the substance initially targeted.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• This is a theoretical calculation applicable primarily to plasma exchange procedures; removal efficiencies will vary somewhat in practice based on what is being removed and its total body distribution.
  • The equation assumes a strictly intravascular substance; this is not necessarily true in routine clinical practice and the less intravascular a substance, the poorer the efficiency of removal.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Can be useful to determine the number of plasma volumes to be exchanged to achieve a reduction in a targeted substance, particularly at the onset of a therapeutic plasma exchange procedure.
  • Provides a sense of the futility of doing many plasma exchanges, as it shows the degree of diminishing returns once a plateau for efficient removal is reached.

next_steps.advice_en: Discuss with apheresis nursing and technical staff the number of plasma volumes to be exchanged.

about.formula_en:
Residual relative concentration, % = 100 * e-x

Where x = plasma volume, mL x number of plasma volumes to be exchanged / total blood volume, mL

Original/Primary Reference.text: Reverberi R, Reverberi L. Removal kinetics of therapeutic apheresis. Blood Transfus. 2007;5(3):164-74.

Other References.text: Kellogg RM, Hester JP. Kinetics modeling of plasma exchange: intra- and post-plasma exchange. J Clin Apher. 1988;4(4):183-7.

expert_name.description: Ronald "George" Hauser, MD, is an assistant professor in laboratory medicine at Yale University School of Medicine who splits his time between clinical medicine and informatics research. As an attending physician, he practices medicine at the interface between other clinicians and the clinical laboratories, which include Chemistry, Hematology, Microbiology, and the Blood Bank. He also works along with medical residents, particularly at the Veterans Affairs Hospital in West Haven, Connecticut. He practices clinical informatics for various projects affiliated at Yale University and the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) including the Recipient Epidemiology and Donor Evaluation Study (REDS; Yale, NIH) and the HIV, Hepatitis, and Related Conditions program (VHA).
